Re weaponized Keynseiasm, my advice to President Obama is that he should fire back immediately that the real threat to our ability to maintain our national defense is the GOP's proposed tax cuts.

The President has very strong credibility on foreign and security policy. His strategic pivot toward Asia is a necessary and important move. He can now say that the Republicans, by proposing tax cuts without saying what spending they are going to cut, will inevitably undermine our national defense budget. The GOP's promise to cut taxes and reduce the deficit make it inevitable that military spending will be affected.

The argument that these people do work others won't do is specious. A few years ago a chicken processing plant had an was raided by INS. OVer 350 illegals were found working there. Underpaid and with repetitive motion injuries. Afraid to report injuries because they could be fired. The plant shut down for a few months and when it reopened it had found 350 local people to work there. It's a poor area and jobs are few. Wages are low and literacy rates are the lowest in the state.
How did they find all these people right around the corner? By paying fair wages, offering health insurance and allowing people to go to a doctor when injured on the job. The problem in this case was unscrupulous business owners.

The unemployment rate among the very young (16-24 years old) is sky high: 17.3% in 2011. They dropped out of the labor force in August in huge numbers, discouraged by poor job prospects. The labor force participation rate for people 16-24 years of age has dropped from 64.1 percent in 2001 to 54.1% today.

Where are the jobs for these kids?

All those who say "illegal immigrants only take jobs that Americans don't want" are now cheering that they can compete for jobs that Americans do want and it's too bad millions of others are not given the privilege of competing for those jobs too.

Too bad their supporters can't keep their story straight. It is too bad that they can't face the issue honestly.

If we can't find jobs for those who are already here; if we are wasting the talents of our own unemployed college grads -- why do we need these kids studying for their GED?

Undocumented people are subsidising the creature comforts of most Americans through their hard, underpaid work. For that, they are targeted by hate speech, laughable assertions of the lawfulness of Americans in comparison with them, and violence - government violence, rape in for-profit "detention centers" which are really part of the prison corporation complex, and violence by individual Americans who are comfortable targeting people who cannot fight back.

One of the major reasons people come here undocumented is the violence unleashed in their home countries by the unlawful consumption of drugs by Americans.

While Americans provide an unlimited demand for illegal drugs, they also make trafficking of weapons to drug gangsters easy as a piece of cake and provide official support of military tactics against druglords in countries like Mexico to further escalate the violence. Wall Street banks make billions of dollars each year from laundering drug money without fear of criminal prosecution.

I personally know a number of hardworking parents who are here undocumented from countries like Guatemala and Mexico, to flee the mayhem unleashed on their home places by American lawlesness. Yet the same shameless Americans, who feel their weekend joint is their right, call these people "illegals."

Most illegal immigrants can't speak English and have minimal schooling. The idea that we need them for their qualifications is ABSURD. They are competing for the worst jobs with the least skilled.

And there is no law of economics that says a particular job is an $8/hr job and that can never change. Illegal immigrants make jobs $8 hour jobs when Americans won't accept such low pay. Without the illegal immigrants employers would have to pay more to attract Americans. In fact, many of the jobs that were middle-class blue collar jobs (such as meat packing) now pay poverty wages because of unrestricted immigration.

If the real problem were: "What we need to do is strengthen education and prepare people to hold those jobs" -- then why would we need to bring in millions more unskilled immigrants.

Just saying "it is much more complicated" is not an excuse for not being able to justify one's position.

The basic supply and demand model may be more complicated than advocates of illegal immigration can deal with, but it does a good job explaining why unrestricted illegal immigration, high unemployment among the unskilled and falling wages go hand-in-hand.

It's important to note, that many are watching online these days. Not sure if your TV ratings comment accounts for that. I watched all the speeches on my computer, both live and after the fact. Point is, many may not be watching live, but I guarantee the halo effect of chatter from a good or bad speech is being watched through all forms of social media. And is affecting sentiment after the fact.

Joshua -- I understand how weather forecasting works. I aver that there is a fundamental difference between saying "conditions X, Y, and Z existed together 100 times in our record of past days, and on 75 of those days it rained" versus "there is a 75% chance of rain on the next day conditions X, Y, and Z exist together." The first is a statement of experience; the second a statement of experience plus faith (and like faith it can't be disproved -- if it doesn't rain, that was just part of the 25% right?). I admit "meaningless" is not quite the right word; I was trying to point to this faith-based and disprovable nature of statistical prediction.

To look at the full equation let’s not forget the scam artists who promise to consolidate loans, erase defaults, end garnishments, “personalize your repayment plan” and lower repayments to “as little as $5 per month” – all for an upfront fee.   These are the same slime balls who preyed on people facing foreclosure,

First of all, a huge thank you to Andrew Martin for drawing attention to this growing crisis.  And, yes it is a crisis.  It is so heartening to find that there is still is some serious, investigative reporting going on.  Sometimes it seems reporters and journalists just follow their higher-ups' bullet points.  The most important thing to do is to make it possible for debtors to pay back what they borrowed with a reasonable interest rate.  Take away compounding and capitalized interest.  Do not punish those who are already financially struggling and doing all they can to make payments by adding egregious consolidation fees which only further add to their financial burden making it almost impossible to get out of debt.  Interest compounds on interest ad infinitum and it seems like payments never get to reducing the actual principal.  Once anyone has paid an amount equal to the amount they originally borrowed, do not let any principal compound beyond, say 10 - 20%.  Anyone who has paid what they borrowed plus that amount, stamp their account PAID IN FULL.  Let's all remember the original mission of the student loan program, which was to make a college education affordable to all.  What happened?  It seems the student loan system has tossed aside its original best practices and Elizabeth Warren is right when she says the system is now rigged against us.

Why not redeem that can you're kicking down the road? It's worth a nickel.

The system is rigged against our youth. You can’t get a job without a college degree, and you can’t go to college without getting into debt (even state schools cost more than 50K for a 4yr degree). If you’re lucky enough to get a job, it certainly will not offer the stability or income, that those same jobs used to offer. Most likely, recent grads will have to intern in the hope that the experience will propel them towards a position with a living wage or become a contractor, which at least offers a salary, but no benefits.

As a recent graduate with an advanced degree, I don’t know of a single peer whose place of employment offers health benefits. They are contract workers, who work side jobs, live in shoe-box apartments, all while trying to pay off loans and hoping that they don’t get sick or in an accident. These students haven’t failed. It is the bottom-line (a.k.a underbid contracts), maximizing efficiency (a.k.a. doing too much without enough staff), profits over people (a.k.a hire contractors instead of having full time employees) attitude that is failing our society.

When asked which tax loop holes Romney would close, Paul Ryan failed to answer. "We want an open process," he said. The would-be Emperor's policy plans, specific details, personal tax returns, or reasons why his personal money is in 23 offshore accounts, remain guarded mysteries.

Beyond partisan differences, and the huge leverage of money, the rabid extremes of the GOP base, something is deeply distributing about both Romney and Ryan. Their flaws are ignored by a media that doesn't challenge them and a public denied a voice in what is a one-sided conversation. Both silence and noise hide their desire for power without process. The substance of their campaign is a hollow promise: we have plans we refuse to disclose until we are elected. They are eager to use democracy to conceal their intent. They offer no covenant with voters. The keys to the national treasury and oversight of all of the nation's regulations and the protections of opportunity, merit, and aid in an open society are sought by default.

The party of voter ids is issuing policy blindfolds. Having no jobs bill or policy, they blindly want voters to believe that their tax cut policy will lift demand (without raising wages!). They propose government by chimera and charade.

Mainiac: I *never* defended all traditional schools. I went to a public high school where 40% of my incoming senior class dropped out or failed to graduate. I know all about what bad public school looks like. That is not what this is about. The trouble is that the author just assumes that she knows everything she needs to know to take her kid to the next level -- that she is *already* a better alternative than the admittedly good public school around the corner. I'm not buying that. I have heard some good reasons why parents have elected to homeschool, but this lady isn't hitting on any of them.

I fully defend the right of religious people to send their kids to religious school and homeschool them (subject to reasonable state laws requiring curriculum review and testing), but I still grieve when ignorant adults exercise that freedom to the detriment of innocent children. I appreciate that I live in a country where I am free to own a nice set of kitchen knives, but I don't appreciate when kitchen knives are used to kill people.

What is being described by the Republicans is party over country.

At what point does purposely damaging the United States, for the purpose of political gain become betrayal, treachery, or even cross over to treason?

There are enough instances of the Republican lawmakers voting against plans and initiatives they were previously for, so in numerous instances they cannot claim a genuine debate over policy. They are obstructing and damaging the country for the specific purpose of defeating the President.

The argument comes down to this in assessing Republican behavior: We feel President Obama is dangerous for the country, and therefore it reasonable that we takes steps that demonstrably harm the country, for the greater good of denying him continuing office.

This is a very cynical argument. One could ask, is it OK for one to rob a bank to garner campaign funds in order to better one's opponent?

At some points politics can not be cover for what otherwise might be considered unacceptabe behavior. At what point does purposely and knowingly harming the United States, as a focus of ones act, justify the majority of the People and their Representatives taking action to prevent or punish that act?

I think those balanced budget constitutions at the State level are a good idea. We've seen legislature after legislature over-borrow and ruin state-after-state. They can't print money. So, there is no safety valve for poor fiscal policy.

If you add the softening affect of the Federal Government supporting states in hard times, you seem to have the right mix. (Perhaps the Federal government getting that help repaid in good times should be part of the mix).

However, this means the Federal government has to act to help when times turn tough. It didn't, not enough, this time.

If not that only some exogenous stimulus (government spending ) will help the economy to grow in the short run. In the long run all markets will correct. But as Keynes said we are all dead in the long run .
